M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the alleged breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment arose within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the monetary damages sought are within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper before the Worcester District Court under M.G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Worcester, where the Plaintiff resides and the Property is located.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s failure to resolve the ongoing mouse infestation has substantially interfered with Plaintiff’s ability to use and enjoy the Property, in violation of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: Numerous Massachusetts cases have held landlords liable for breaches of this covenant due to infestations or other health hazards.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard of landlord fault required to establish a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment (at least negligence and notice), but it does not catalogue or hold that “numerous Massachusetts cases” have imposed landlord liability for infestations or other health hazards. The cited prior cases (Simon, Cruz, Darmetko, Dorgan, Doe) involve failures to repair defects or control flooding, not infestations or generalized health hazards, and the court here focuses on lead paint and attorney’s fees, not on that broader proposition.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: Numerous Massachusetts cases have held landlords liable for breaches of this covenant due to infestations or other health hazards.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that numerous Massachusetts cases have held landlords liable for breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment specifically due to infestations or other health hazards. Simon v. Solomon involves sewage flooding and unsanitary conditions and discusses warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment, but it does not survey or rely on “numerous Massachusetts cases” imposing quiet-enjoyment liability for infestations or health hazards generally. It is itself one case involving flooding, and its discussion of prior cases focuses on warranty/Code violations and quiet enjoyment doctrine, not on multiple infestation/health-hazard precedents, so it does not support the breadth of the claimed proposition.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing. See, e.g., G. L. c. 111, §§ 127A-127L, c. 186, §§ 14, 15E, 15F, 18, 19; c. 239, § 8A. These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 191-193 (1973). The objectives of these statutes go beyond deterrence of intentional wrongdoing; unsanitary conditions in an apartment cause harm to the occupants whether the landlord has acted intentionally, negligently, or innocently.”}```

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Numerous Massachusetts cases have held landlords liable for breaches of this covenant due to infestations or other health hazards.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case discusses landlord liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of criminal activity/drug dealing and security measures, not infestations or traditional health hazards. The court does not survey or rely on “numerous Massachusetts cases” imposing liability for covenant-of-quiet-enjoyment breaches based on infestations or similar health conditions; instead, its review of such prior cases concerns noise, access, and use of premises. Therefore, this opinion does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880, 884 (1988). Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987). Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 167 (1985). Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102. In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions.”

M.G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127L.proposition: Additionally, under M.G.L. c. 111, § 127L, landlords have a statutory duty to maintain their properties in a condition that complies with the State Sanitary Code.

105 C.M.R. 410.550.proposition: The presence of pests, such as mice, violates 105 C.M.R. 410.550, which mandates landlords to address infestations promptly.

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take adequate measures is also contrary to established caselaw prioritizing tenants’ rights to sanitary conditions, including *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, 200 (1973) (landlord obligations under warranty of habitability apply to issues such as infestations); *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 664 (1977) (landlord liable for failure to maintain property free of pests).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway is a concurring/dissenting opinion focused on recognizing an implied landlord obligation tied to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and the warranty of habitability generally. In the provided text, there is no specific discussion of infestations or pests, nor a clear statement that landlord obligations under the warranty of habitability apply to infestations in particular. Thus, while the case broadly supports tenant rights to sanitary, habitable conditions, this excerpt does not directly support the narrower proposition that the warranty specifically covers infestations.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..raw_text: *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 664 (1977)
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to take adequate measures is also contrary to established caselaw prioritizing tenants’ rights to sanitary conditions, including *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, 200 (1973) (landlord obligations under warranty of habitability apply to issues such as infestations); *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 664 (1977) (landlord liable for failure to maintain property free of pests).
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..support_reasoning: King concerns a landlord’s tort duty to maintain common areas (a stairway) in reasonably safe condition for tenants and their visitors; it does not address infestations, sanitary conditions, or any specific obligation to keep premises free of pests. The holding is about adopting a general, continuing duty of reasonable care for common areas, not about pest control. Characterizing King as establishing that a landlord is liable for failure to maintain property free of pests overstates and misdescribes the decision.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors… The landlord should not be allowed to remain in such a position that he has no incentive to maintain the areas retained under his control in reasonably safe condition… [T]he point in time at which the dangerous condition came into existence is only important as a factor in determining whether the landlord could have discovered the condition by the exercise of reasonable care and whether he has had a reasonable time to make it safe.”
